awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Robustness Guided Testing and Verification for Cyber-Physical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This project develops a theoretical framework as well as software tools to support testing and verification of a Cyber-Physical System (CPS) within a Model-Based Design (MBD) process. The theoretical bases of the framework are stochastic optimization methods, and robustness notions of formal specification languages. The project's research comprises three components: development of conditions on the algorithms and on the structure of the CPS for inferring finite-time guarantees on the randomized testing process; the study of testing methods that can support modular and compositional system design; and investigation of appropriate notions of conformance between two system models and between a model and its implementation on a computational platform. All of these components are needed to support testing and verification in all the stages of an MBD process as well as to support component reuse, incremental system improvements and modular design. The evaluation of the framework is driven by the problems of verifying automotive control systems and medical devices. 

As safety-critical CPS become ubiquitous, the need for design methods that guarantee correct system functionality and performance becomes more urgent. Certification and government agencies need dependable testing and verification tools to incorporate in certification standards and procedures. The concrete benefits to the society are both in terms of reduced catastrophic design errors in new products and in terms of reduced economic costs for new product development. The former increases the confidence in new technologies while the latter improves the competitiveness of the companies that utilize such technologies. The theoretical results of this project are being incorporated into software tools for testing, verification and validation of complex CPS. The evaluation focus of the project on verifying infusion pumps and automotive control software ultimately helps in avoiding harmful losses due to errors in these safety-critical systems. The use of any software tool that is based on formal or semi-formal methods requires engineers with solid training on these technologies. This proposal puts forward an education curriculum for developing new courses that introduce formal and semi-formal methods for CPS at all levels of higher education, i.e., undergraduate, graduate and continuing education. Particular attention is devoted into on-line continuing education of practicing engineers who must acquire new MBD skills.

por.por_cntn:
This project developed the theoretical foundations and software tools for addressing the problem of automated test generation for Cyber-Physical Systems (CPS). CPS includes all systems where a computer interacts closely with the physical environment. CPS promise to address many of the technological concerns of modern societies: better medical devices, safer and more efficient transportation, distributed power grids, etc. Such systems are primarily safety critical, which means human lives depend on their safe operation. However, currently, we are facing a major technological challenge on how to verify and certify the correct operation of CPS. The complexity lies in multiple factors, but there at least two important challenges. First, CPS must adhere to complex requirements and, hence, it is not easy for humans to come up with test scenarios to explore corner cases (off nominal use scenarios). Second, even when a human could produce a relevant test scenario for a given requirement, it is hard even for experts to predict the unintended consequences resulting from the cyber and physical component interactions.

In this project, we addressed the aforementioned challenges by investigating the framework of requirements guided automated test case generation through the notion of requirements? robustness. Our project went above and beyond these two challenges to address problems of adequacy of test coverage (needed for certification), conformance testing (needed for hardware implementations), and modularity of testing (needed at least for conditional requirements). We demonstrated the benefits of our approach to test generation for automotive systems and, more recently, for Automated Driving Systems (ADS). With our work, it is now possible to test ADS under open scenarios and focus testing on parameters where the vehicle under test is at-fault. Our software tools for test case generation are open source and publicly available under the brand of S-TaLiRo tools:

https://sites.google.com/a/asu.edu/s-taliro/

Among the broader impacts of our work, our team established an international competition category for CPS testing (also known as falsification) in the international workshop on Applied Verification for Continuous and Hybrid Systems (ARCH). Every year since 2017, the participants to the competition have been increasing by 1-3 teams indicating a growing research interest in the domain.

In summary, our work resulted in and/or contributed to:

  1. 4 journal papers, 2 survey/tutorial papers, and 19 conference papers
  2. 1 issued patent and 2 patent applications
  3. 4 PhD thesis
  4. 2 conference paper awards and 1 PhD dissertation award
  5. Graduate course material for test generation in CPS
  6. A Computer Science robotics class that places equal value in both physical and cyber aspects of robotics
